author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Something Special
description: August Miller’s puzzle offers some words of comfort.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Hello and happy Monday, solvers! Today’s puzzle features some sage words from the constructor August Miller, although you may need to solve the puzzle all the way through to uncover what they are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: ‘He’s the Best Player in the World’
description: The Byron Buxton Experience is finally happening for the Minnesota Twins and the team could not be happier. A little caution along the way can’t hurt.
content: BALTIMORE — This is the Byron Buxton Experience, condensed into a four-game series last week between the Minnesota Twins and the Baltimore Orioles at Camden Yards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia’s Pre-Holiday Push
description: Plus Hong Kong’s new leader and a Taliban decree targeting women’s dress.
content: Today is Russia’s Victory Day, a militaristic holiday that commemorates the Soviet Union’s defeat of the Nazis in World War II. Under President Vladimir Putin, the holiday has come to celebrate modern Russian military might.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Rich Strike’s Derby Win Has Given Horse Racing a Welcome Reboot
description: The colt’s jockey, trainer and owner are anything but racing royalty, but they are the kind of story the sport needs right now.
content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — By Sunday afternoon, Eric Reed’s eyes were hooded, and his voice was as scratchy as a transistor radio. He had been unable to sleep, thanks to the entirely welcome replay loop of his colt Rich Strike scooting up the rail of Churchill Downs and into the history books as the 80-1 winner of the 148th Kentucky Derby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Ayala
title: Lynx’s Sylvia Fowles Does Not See Final Season as a Victory Lap
description: The well-decorated Fowles plans to retire after the 2022 season. But while she reluctantly welcomes the celebrations, she is focused on basketball.
content: After this, her 15th season, Minnesota Lynx center Sylvia Fowles will call it a career. Friday was the beginning of Syl’s Final Ride, as the team is calling it — a season-long celebration of one of the best to ever play in a Lynx uniform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: The Week in Business: More Strong Job Gains
description: The Federal Reserve approved its biggest rate increase since 2000. Investors joined Elon Musk’s deal to buy Twitter. Another inflation indicator comes out this week.
content: The Labor Department reported another solid month of job growth in April on Friday. U.S. employers added 428,000 jobs, the department said, the same as the revised figure for March. The unemployment rate in April remained at 3.6 percent. The United States has regained nearly 95 percent of the 22 million jobs lost at the height of pandemic lockdowns. Employers’ scramble for workers as the economy has recovered helped push up wages — the April survey showed average hourly earnings 5.5 percent higher than a year earlier — but those gains for workers have been largely offset by a surge in prices. The labor supply has not kept up with job openings, and the labor force shrank unexpectedly in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Both Sides Harden Positions on Anniversary of Nazi Defeat in Europe
description: The war in Ukraine was marked by posturing and signaling, with each side ramping up its rhetoric as the battle ground on.
content: PARIS — On a day of commemoration of the end of World War II in Europe, the war in Ukraine was marked by posturing and signaling on Sunday, as each side ramped up its rhetoric and resolve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: If Roe Falls, Is Same-Sex Marriage Next?
description: The leaked draft opinion that would eliminate the constitutional right to abortion sent mixed signals about what other precedents might be at risk.
content: WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court heard arguments in December over the fate of the constitutional right to abortion, it was already clear that other rights, notably including same-sex marriage, could be at risk if the court overruled Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Trump Ally in Nebraska Opens Feuds in G.O.P.
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 8, 2022.
content: “This is a proxy war between the entire Republican establishment in America against President Donald J. Trump.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Mooallem, Jack D'Isidoro, Elisheba Ittoop, John Woo and Dan Farrell
title: The Sunday Read: ‘It Was Just a Kayaking Trip. Until It Upended Our Lives.’
description: Three friends set out on a sea-kayaking trip through Glacier Bay National Park in Alaska, having a good time, when tragedy struck.
content: It was meant to mark the start of their lives out of college, but the adventure quickly turned into a nightmare. Beginning with what seemed to be a lucky whale sighting, three friends set out on a sea-kayaking trip through Glacier Bay National Park in Alaska, watching out for bears, and having a good time, when tragedy struck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Connie Schultz
title: How Can a Safari Go Wrong? Let’s Count the Ways.
description: In Chris Bohjalian’s new novel, “The Lioness,” a trip to the Serengeti turns bloody.
content: The film star Katie Barstow thinks she is doing a wonderful thing. She wants to celebrate her honeymoon not just with her new husband, the struggling art gallery owner David Hill, but with a herd of their Hollywood friends. Their party of nine includes her brother and his wife, another actress and an actor, plus her publicist and agent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Alexandra Stevenson
title: Beijing’s Man in Hong Kong Inherits a Tamed City
description: John Lee, who won a rubber-stamp leadership election on Sunday, will implement the next stage of China’s agenda for the former British colony.
content: HONG KONG — John Lee “will make Hong Kongers and international investors feel relaxed, at ease and full of confidence,” a pro-Beijing newspaper declared. He will help the city “start anew to achieve greater glories,” the state-run China Daily wrote, in one of a series of articles praising him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Supreme Court Leak Inquiry Exposes Gray Area of Press Protections
description: No law or written code of conduct prescribes how an investigation into the leak of a draft opinion should proceed, or whether journalists will be swept into it.
content: There is a well-established but uneven pattern in American law that applies to government secrets and the journalists who uncover them. The First Amendment generally protects the publication of a leak, but not the leaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Jan Ransom
title: Man, 25, Is the Fourth Inmate to Die at Rikers This Year
description: Dashawn Carter was found hanging in his cell in an apparent suicide during a time of deepening crisis for the jail.
content: A 25-year-old homeless man is believed to have committed suicide at the Rikers Island jail complex in New York City on Saturday evening, according to people familiar with the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: A Haven for L.G.B.T.Q. Students in the Heart of Alabama
description: The Magic City Acceptance Academy, a public charter school, finally opened last year after several attempts. Students there have watched state legislators debate their future in real time.
content: HOMEWOOD, Ala. — Since a brand-new charter school opened its doors in a suburb of Birmingham, Ala., last fall, there have been a few disturbances along the periphery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: If Roe Is Overturned, Where Should the Pro-Life Movement Go Next?
description: “Now is not the time to brag or gloat or celebrate. Now is the time to get to work.”
content: Pro-life activists have been working toward overturning the Supreme Court’s Roe v. Wade decision ever since it came down in 1973. But as I spoke to folks from pro-life and whole-life movements last week after the leak of a draft opinion that indicated the court will overturn Roe, the mood was complicated. I did not find unalloyed jubilance or triumph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: May 9 Is a Revered Day in Russia. For Many, Putin Has Hijacked It.
description: Under President Vladimir V. Putin, Victory Day, marking the defeat of Nazi Germany, has come to celebrate modern Russian military might. The war in Ukraine is shifting its meaning further.
content: Olga Romanova’s grandmother served as a frontline nurse in World War II. She was small and thin, Ms. Romanova said, but somehow carried “big, grown, wounded men” to safety. She met her husband in her four years on the eastern front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Mickey Gilley, Country Star Whose Club Inspired ‘Urban Cowboy,’ Dies at 86
description: His records regularly made the charts for two decades. But he was ultimately best known for his Texas nightclub, which was at the heart of a country music revival.
content: Mickey Gilley, the singer and piano player whose Texas nightclub was the inspiration for the movie “Urban Cowboy” and the glittering country music revival that accompanied it, died on Saturday at a hospital in Branson, Mo. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
title: Good News for Food, Bad News for War: Brazil Buys Russian Fertilizer
description: Officials expected the war to trap up to 15 percent of the world’s fertilizer exports in Russia. But Brazil and other countries have found a way to get it.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — When the first Russian missiles struck Ukraine, the reverberations were felt 6,500 miles away, on the vast Brazilian farms that grow much of the world’s soybeans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: 3 Americans Die in Mysterious Circumstances at Bahamas Resort
description: It was unclear what happened but officials said they did not suspect foul play and there were no signs of trauma. Another guest was hospitalized in stable condition.
content: Three Americans died under mysterious circumstances and another was hospitalized on Friday while they were staying at the Sandals Resort on Great Exuma Island in the Bahamas, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: TikTok May Be More Dangerous Than It Looks
description: The social media platforms that hold and shape our attention need to be governed in the public interest.
content: At the core of the frenzied interest in Elon Musk’s acquisition of Twitter is an intuition that I think is right: The major social media platforms are, in some hard-to-define way, essential to modern life. Call them town squares. Call them infrastructure. They exist in some nether region between public utility and private concern. They are too important to entrust to billionaires and businesses, but that makes them too dangerous to hand over to governments. We have not yet found a satisfying answer to the problem of their ownership and governance. But some arrangements are more worrying than others. There are fates worse than Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Dmitry Bivol Outclasses Canelo Álvarez in Big Upset for Boxing
description: Álvarez was outpunched over 12 rounds by the bigger Bivol, who stayed undefeated and found himself being asked for an immediate rematch.
content: LAS VEGAS — In the closing moments of the final round of the light-heavyweight title fight between Saúl Álvarez and Dmitry Bivol, a ringside official banged a wooden clapper to signal that only 10 seconds remained in the bout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: ‘Please Help’: A Nationwide Baby Formula Shortage Worsens
description: After Abbott Nutrition issued voluntary recalls of its popular baby formulas, retailers have limited purchases, leaving desperate parents searching for solutions.
content: The manufacturer of Ashley Hernandez’s preferred baby formula for her two girls said it was out of stock on its website. Listings on eBay showed it would cost her up to $120 for a single can. So when she found a seller online offering 10 cans for $40 each, she expressed her desperation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suzanne Finnamore
title: Dementia Is a Place Where My Mother Lives. It Is Not Who She Is.
description: Thinking of it this way creates a boundary between me and the treacherous drop of despair.
content: On a recent Sunday, I brought my 86-year-old mother, Bunny, a tremendously gaudy fake pearl ring with an elastic band. She loved it. Rings are of great value to her now, as they can dazzle and are never out of reach. My mother has dementia, in its final stage. Each time I put the ring on her finger, it will be the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: America, Unmasked
description: Few among us loved the mask when it was forced on us, but it’s worth considering what we’re losing as it disappears.
content: Our masks are finally coming off. As mandates across the country are lifted or struck down, we can breeze out of the house, nose and chin fully on display, face bare to the wind. How odd that something so basic has become something of a marvel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Seizing an Oligarch’s Assets Is One Thing. Giving Them to Ukraine Is Another.
description: It could take years for Russian assets seized by the United States to be permanently confiscated and sold to benefit the Ukrainian people. The Biden administration wants to speed up the process.
content: The U.S. government was so pleased with its swift seizure of a Russian oligarch’s 255-foot yacht on the Mediterranean island of Majorca last month that it posted a video on YouTube of the moment F.B.I. agents and Spanish authorities clambered up the gangplank. The $90 million yacht owned by Viktor Vekselberg, called the Tango, was the government’s first big prize in a campaign against billionaires with close ties to the Kremlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jill Biden’s Secret Ukraine Trip
description: Ukrainian officials reached out several days ahead of Dr. Biden’s planned four-day tour of Eastern Europe to suggest a meeting with the Ukrainian first lady. The East Wing took the chance.
content: UZHHOROD, Ukraine — Jill Biden, the first lady, traveled to western Ukraine in an unannounced trip on Sunday, the latest show of support from the United States, which in recent weeks has significantly increased military aid for Ukraine and sent others close to President Biden into the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Vander Ploeg and Addison Lathers
title: Anti-Abortion Group in Wisconsin Is Hit by Arson, Authorities Say
description: A Molotov cocktail was used against Wisconsin Family Action in Madison and did not ignite, but another fire was set, the police said.
content: The headquarters of an anti-abortion group in Madison, Wis., was set on fire on Sunday morning in an act of vandalism that included the attempted use of a Molotov cocktail and graffiti that read “If abortions aren’t safe then you aren’t either,” according to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Supreme Court as an Instrument of Oppression
description: In just a few short weeks, the fundamental right enshrined in Roe nearly 50 years ago could disappear overnight. What’s next? Is anything safe?
content: If you focus on the Supreme Court’s expansion of equal rights since the 1950s, you could see Justice Samuel Alito’s stunning, leaked draft opinion as a shocking, anomalous reversal, a decision at odds with the trajectory of the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Senate Democrats Warn of G.O.P. Effort to Restrict Abortion Nationwide
description: The alarms came after Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, called such a ban “possible” if a leaked Supreme Court opinion became final and his party gained control in Washington.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats rang alarm bells on Sunday about the likelihood that Republicans would try to restrict abortion nationwide, two days after an interview was published in which Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the minority leader, said a ban was “possible” if his party gained control in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary, Safiullah Padshah and Kiana Hayeri
title: Eid Under the Taliban Shows a Changed Afghanistan
description: For many Afghans the holiday this past week served as a reminder of the dissonance between the promise of peace many had imagined and the realities of the end of the war.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Thousands of Afghans had piled into buses and set out down the country’s once perilous highways bound for relatives they had not seen in years. Afghanistan’s only national park was filled with tourists who had only dreamed of traveling to its intensely blue lakes and jagged mountains when fighting raged across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin and Scott Reyburn
title: Warhol’s $200 Million ‘Marilyn’ Could Test Art Market’s Health
description: The painting is poised to wrest the auction high for an American artwork from Jean-Michel Basquiat.
content: In 1985, the dealer Tony Shafrazi designed a poster promoting his show of paintings made jointly by Andy Warhol and Jean-Michel Basquiat. The image featured the two artists in boxing gloves as if preparing to spar with one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin P. Russell
title: Fernanda Melchor Explores the Human Capacity for Violence, and Grace
description: “Art must leave a wound,” said the author, one of the most celebrated in new Latin American literature.
content: MEXICO CITY — Fernanda Melchor’s Mexico is no place for fairy tales: Young girls are raped and cast aside, adolescent boys are turned into assassins and made grist for the mill of narcoviolence. The underworld of her fiction offers few comforts and fewer opportunities, an imagined landscape — for some a reality — that might be easier to wall off and ignore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel and Annie Flanagan
title: Hundreds of Suicidal Teens Sleep in Emergency Rooms. Every Night.
description: With inpatient psychiatric services in short supply, adolescents are spending days, even weeks, in hospital emergency departments awaiting the help they desperately need.
content: On a rainy Thursday evening last spring, a 15-year-old girl was rushed by her parents to the emergency department at Boston Children’s Hospital. She had marks on both wrists from self-harm and a recent suicide attempt, and earlier that day she confided to her pediatrician that she planned to try again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: An N.B.A. Star Who Can’t Watch N.B.A. Games? It’s About Bad Habits.
description: “I have principles when it comes to this game,” Phoenix Suns center Deandre Ayton said. So when others don’t seem to, he said, “I don’t watch it at all.”
content: Do not ask Phoenix Suns center Deandre Ayton to watch the N.B.A. away from work. He doesn’t want to see other teams play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Imagines the Origins of Abortion Law
description: On an episode hosted by Benedict Cumberbatch, “Saturday Night Live” contemplated the possibility that the Supreme Court could overturn Roe v. Wade.
content: “Saturday Night Live” dug deep for its opening sketch this weekend, far into the text of a leaked draft opinion indicating that the Supreme Court has voted to overturn the Roe v. Wade decision, at the section where the draft opinion’s author, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., cites legal theory from 13th century England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Midterms’ Biggest Abortion Battleground: Pennsylvania
description: The leading Republicans running for governor in the state want to outlaw abortion. The presumptive Democratic nominee promises to veto any ban.
content: HANOVER TOWNSHIP, Pa. — Jan Downey, who calls herself “a Catholic Republican,” is so unhappy about the Supreme Court’s likely reversal of abortion rights that she is leaning toward voting for a Democrat for Pennsylvania governor this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Dozens are feared dead after a Russian airstrike hits a school building, officials say.
description: Initial reports suggested that as many as 60 people were trapped inside the building, which officials said was being used as a shelter for civilians.
content: Dozens of people are feared dead after a Russian airstrike leveled a school in eastern Ukraine on Saturday, local officials said, as Russian forces kept up their unrelenting bombardment of towns and cities across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and David A. Fahrenthold
title: Head of U.N. Agency Resigns After Questions Arise About Loans
description: The little-known organization gave out $61 million in loans and grant money to a single British family, in a scandal that has shaken and embarrassed the U.N.
content: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, asked a top official at a U.N. agency to resign on Saturday, shortly after The New York Times published an article describing how the agency had given out $61 million in loans and grant money to a single British family, according to a senior U.N. official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Gov. Kathy Hochul Tests Positive for Covid
description: The New York governor’s exposure comes as the state battles yet another variant that is more transmissible than previous versions of the virus.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York announced on Sunday that she had tested positive for the coronavirus — the worst sort of Mother’s Day surprise for the state’s first mom governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: Igor Levit Arrives at the Philharmonic, at Last
description: Levit, one of the world’s eminent pianists, appeared with the orchestra at Carnegie Hall eight years after making his New York debut.
content: Eight years ago, a young pianist made his New York debut with a brazen program of Beethoven’s final sonatas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: ‘Falling Out of Time’ Gives Song to a Father’s Grief
description: Osvaldo Golijov’s evening-length work, based on the book by David Grossman about his son, had its New York premiere at Zankel Hall.
content: I didn’t know whether I was the right person to review the New York premiere of Osvaldo Golijov’s song cycle “Falling Out of Time” at Zankel Hall on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Short Time Later, Fernando Was Back for Another Task’
description: An impromptu aria in Inwood, sassy poses at Brighton Beach and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Decade of Drill Rap
description: Pop Smoke, Lil Durk, Fivio Foreign and more have taken the sound that emerged in Chicago in different directions. What might come next?
content: In the early 2010s, a novel sound emerged from Chicago’s rap scene. Drill music was immediate and brash, relentlessly local and yet easily accessible. It became a template that would be borrowed from widely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Dmitry Bivol’s Next Bout Could Be About Money or His Dream
description: A rematch with Canelo Álvarez would be lucrative, but Bivol made a competition-based argument for moving on from him.
content: LAS VEGAS — Dmitry Bivol sat at the crowded head table, between his manager, Vadim Kornilov, and his promoter, Eddie Hearn, and beamed as he addressed reporters in a packed room at T-Mobile Arena late Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Captures 2 Palestinians Suspected in Deadly Ax Attack
description: The two men were caught hiding in a forest not far from where the killings were carried out, ending an intensive search. But the country remains on high alert.
content: JERUSALEM — Israeli security forces captured two Palestinians on Sunday who were suspected of perpetrating an ax attack that killed three Israeli Jews in the central town of Elad on Thursday night. Their arrests ended an intensive search but left Israel’s fragile government grappling with how to combat the recent surge in terrorist attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi
title: A Pot of U.N. Money. Risk-Taking Officials. A Sea of Questions.
description: A little-known United Nations agency decided to make an impact by doling out loans and grant money — all to a single family. It did not go well.
content: At the United Nations, two officials had a problem. The little-known agency they ran found itself with an extra $61 million, and they didn’t know what to do with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: George Pérez, Who Gave New Life to Wonder Woman, Dies at 67
description: Working for both Marvel and DC, he created comic book series that brought superheroes together, and was co-creator of The New Teen Titans.
content: George Pérez, a celebrated comic book artist and writer who gave new life to Wonder Woman in the 1980s and helped create series for DC Comics and Marvel Comics that brought together some of the biggest heroes of the comics world, including The New Teen Titans, died on Friday at his home in Sanford, Fla. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: The Shifting State of Feminism in America
description: The feminist movement in the 1970s helped create the social conditions that brought about Roe v. Wade. But will modern feminism have the coherence to determine what comes after?
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: As Poor Nations Seek Covid Pills, Officials Fear Repeat of AIDS Crisis
description: The antiviral pills, plentiful in the United States, are scarce overseas. Health groups and the White House want to expand access but face obstacles that evoke the H.I.V. epidemic.
content: WASHINGTON — A devastating virus was laying waste to nations that lacked medicines available to Americans. The pills were patented and pricey. Poor countries lacked refrigeration to store them, the thinking went, and patients would not be able to follow the complex dosing regimen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: A Leak That Slowed, but Did Not Stop, the Presses
description: Here’s how the Times report on the leaked Supreme Court draft opinion to overturn Roe v. Wade came together — and made it into print.
content: On Monday night, an alert popped into a New York Times internal messaging channel: A draft United States Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade and end federal protection of abortion rights had been leaked and published. A court leak was an incredibly rare event and, if the document was confirmed as authentic, the decision would reshape women’s access to abortion in many states and send a shock through U.S. politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Jimenez Moya, Scott Atkinson, Robert Chiarito and Lola Fadulu
title: Weekend of Abortion Protests Brings Out Supporters
description: Rallies in Houston and Chicago were among numerous events planned across the country.
content: HOUSTON — Several thousand people in Texas’ largest city rallied for abortion rights on Saturday, one of numerous demonstrations held across the country days after a draft opinion from the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade was leaked. They were joined by a host of Democratic officials, including former Representative Beto O’Rourke, who is running for governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: A Knave Competed in the Sport of Kings, and Instantly Became One
description: At the Kentucky Derby, the 80-1 long shot Rich Strike showed that horse racing isn’t just for the humans and horses with fancy pedigrees.
content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The Sport of Kings. Ha!
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 8, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 8, 2022.
content: An article on April 24 about George Pele­canos and “We Own This City” described incorrectly his role as showrunner. It is not his first time to serve as showrunner of a series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Ed Koch’s Secret
description: He defined the role of a big-city mayor, but his personal secret affected his response to a major crisis.
content: Ed Koch, the former mayor of New York, had a bombastic style that defined the image of a big-city leader in the 1980s. But as open as Koch could be, my colleagues Matt Flegenheimer and Rosa Goldensohn wrote in a new profile of him, he strained to conceal one aspect of his life: He was gay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Ncuti Gatwa Is the New Doctor on ‘Doctor Who’
description: Mr. Gatwa, a star of the Netflix series “Sex Education,” will be the first Black man to play the lead character in the enduring BBC science fiction franchise.
content: Ncuti Gatwa, a star of the Netflix series “Sex Education,” will be the 14th actor and the first Black man to play the lead role of the Doctor in “Doctor Who,” the long-running British science fiction franchise about a time-traveling adventurer, the BBC announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: A Town for Heady Looks
description: This week’s strongest outfits from the Central Park hat luncheon, the Prince’s Trust gala and the Noguchi Museum honoring Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month.
content: A week already crowded with gowns from the Met Gala was made a little more wild on Wednesday, when the Central Park Conservancy raised $4 million at its 40th annual Frederick Law Olmsted luncheon, fondly known as the “hat lunch.” Despite gray skies, it looked as if the Easter Parade had crashed the Kentucky Derby and landed at the Conservatory Garden near 105th Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Ric Parnell, Real Drummer in a Famous Fake Band, Dies at 70
description: The central characters in the mockumentary “This Is Spinal Tap” were comic actors, but Mr. Parnell was an actual professional musician.
content: Ric Parnell, a real drummer best known for playing in a fake band, the one chronicled in Rob Reiner’s fabled 1984 mockumentary, “This Is Spinal Tap,” died on May 1 in Missoula, Mont., where he had lived for some two decades. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Eduardo Medina
title: G7 nations pledge to ban or phase out Russian oil.
description: With much of Europe dependent on Russian oil, the Group of 7 said the ban would take effect in a “timely and orderly fashion.”
content: Leaders of the Group of 7 nations pledged during a virtual meeting on Sunday with President Volodymyr Zelensky to ban or phase out Russian oil, aiming to still further erode Russia’s economic standing as it pursues its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 9, 2022

title: What’s Your Rate of Inflation?
